I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the governments of the 
developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  promote 
evidence-based policy design on small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) development by (i) 
demonstrating a country and regional index using a multivariate analytical approach, which will 
be accessed by the DMCs; and (ii) providing a comparative country data platform, which will cover 
financial and nonfinancial aspects of SME development in the DMCs and will be updated 
periodically. The TA will also help ADB operations formulate new ideas for SME projects by using 
innovative approaches through pilot project proposals that will be discussed in the Asia SME 
Monitor, an ADB annual publication. 
  
2.  The TA supports the elaboration and expansion of the prior Asia SME Monitor projects 
(phases 1 and 2)1 and the resultant publications. This will enhance the Asia SME Monitor’s 
usefulness and create the basis for its annual issuance with an open data portal as a key resource 
on SME development policies in Asia and the Pacific. The Asia SME Monitors issued in 2014 and 
2015 were knowledge products supporting SME development in the region, especially focusing 
on access to finance. The issues reviewed various country aspects of SME finance, including 
banking, nonbank sectors, and national policy actions, covering 20 DMCs from the five ADB 
regions. The TA will upgrade the prior Asia SME Monitor initiatives by extending analytical 
coverage to nonfinancial issues on SME development and introducing the Small and Medium-
Sized Enterprise Development Index (SME-DI) that comprehensively measures various issues 
affecting SME development at the national and regional levels.  
 
3.  Through the TA, the TA team will help implement ADB’s Strategy 2030 objectives: 
contributing  to  creating  quality  jobs,  promoting  rural  development,  and  fostering  regional 
cooperation and integration.2 Support for SMEs is critical towards achieving these objectives. The 
TA will strengthen ADB’s value addition by providing operationally relevant practical knowledge, 
and partnerships with centers of excellence. The TA is consistent with the 2019 annual work plan 
for the Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department (ERCD), which anticipates 
providing  knowledge  solutions  under  the  One  ADB  approach.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  the 
Operational  Plan  for  Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration,  2016-2020,  especially  with 
operational  direction  2  (raising  competitiveness  in  connected  markets).3 Support  for  SME 
development is also critical for regional financial cooperation.4  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  Continuous economic growth in Asia and the Pacific has helped alleviate poverty and 
allowed a number of countries to transform into middle-income economies. Although developing 
Asia shows robust gross domestic product growth (6.0% in 2018 and expected to reach 5.8% in 
20195), global economic uncertainty, exaggerated by trade tensions and protectionist measures, 
has increased the downside risks to the region’s growth. Potential slower growth requires

and benefits from changing external circumstances to create a resilient base at the national level. 
It is at this level where SMEs play a more central role in promoting sustainable economic growth 
in Asia. 
 
5.  SMEs are a driving force of Asia’s economies, accounting on average for 96% of all 
enterprises and 62% of the national labor force in developing Asia. Their contribution to the growth 
momentum, however, is limited at 42% of each country’s gross domestic product on average in 
the region.6 Economic expansion in Asia has the potential to create a foundation of growth-
oriented SMEs that contribute to boosting national productivity. Such a foundation has not yet 
materialized in most of the DMCs because of a number of factors, such as a lack of SME access 
to appropriate markets and finance. While growth in Asia has created a group of high net worth 
individuals with ample capital available and interest in investment opportunities that support new 
and innovative businesses, several factors including policy matters and the lack of venues for 
investment make it difficult for them to find suitable SMEs to invest in.  
 
6.  SME development is a key policy agenda toward inclusive growth in most DMCs. The 
design of SME policies has become more challenging because of the complexity of the SME 
business environment and the rapidly changing external environment. For instance, the Fourth 
Industrial  Revolution,7 represented  by  emerging  technologies  such  as  artificial  intelligence, 
robotics, and the “internet of things” (IOT)8, has been dramatically changing Asia’s business 
environment and influencing how SMEs operate. While this may have the negative impact of 
reducing the workforce, mainly from large and established firms, it can create more viable SME 
bases, especially technology-based SMEs that support the creation of more quality jobs and 
attract more investments. Technology, as an enabler of innovation, is a key survival tool for 
growth-oriented SMEs including start-up companies. DMC governments will need to monitor 
changing  business  climates  so  that  they  can  design  enforceable  policy  support  for  SME 
development.  
 
7.  Foreign direct investment inflows to Asia, which have been sharply increasing since the 
2007–2008 global financial crisis, also bring business opportunities for SMEs.9 Increased entry of 
large multinational firms into developing Asia creates new demands for domestic products and 
services from SMEs—typically in supporting industries or for parts and components suppliers—
and accordingly will improve labor productivity if SMEs actively participate in global value chains. 
Global value chains bring several benefits to SMEs: increased competitiveness, enhanced 
product quality by technology transfer, business expansion, and job creation. To promote SMEs’ 
participation in global value chains, DMC governments will need to better understand the regional 
and  global  SME  business  landscape  and  neighboring  countries’  policy  practices  through 
strengthened regional cooperation and integration.

8.  The  liberalized  trade  and  investment  brought  about  by  economic  integration  and 
expansion and the advent of advanced technologies will promote the structural changes needed 
for the SME business model, allowing it to move from being domestically focused to being globally 
competitive. This shift requires new policy solutions for emerging growth-oriented SMEs. A rapidly 
changing external environment, as accelerated by the Fourth Industrial Revolution and foreign 
direct investment inflows, will create more opportunities for SME business in developing Asia, but 
appropriate design of policy support is needed for such opportunities to materialize. DMC 
governments  are  seeking  timely  access  to  high-quality  multicountry  analytical  data  and 
neighboring countries’ good practices on SME development so that they can effectively assess 
and implement enforceable SME policies. ADB is in the best position to provide such data and 
policy  advice,  given  its  expertise  in  this  area  and  the  extent  of  projects  supporting  SME 
development across the region. 
 
9.  The DMC governments and ADB operations have a strong demand for the continuous 
delivery of multicountry SME data from ADB with periodic updates, as indicated in the client 
satisfaction surveys after previous Asia SME Monitor projects.10 Participating DMCs were highly 
satisfied with the Asia SME Monitor, stating that it facilitates their effective policy design on SME 
development, encourages data harmonization across countries, and promotes common policy 
discussions on SMEs at the regional and global levels. ADB staff who participated in the surveys 
also indicated the usefulness of the Asia SME Monitor in the design of SME-related projects.   
 
10.  Besides the Asia SME Monitor, there are several global SME data initiatives, but there are 
limitations with data coverage and methodology. For instance, the Organisation for Economic Co-
operation and Development has issued an SME scoreboard annually since 2011, focusing on 
bank credit and nonbank finance in 43 countries. However, it covers only five ADB DMCs (the 
People’s Republic of China, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Malaysia, and Thailand), and each country 
paper is only a two-page data summary. The International Finance Corporation has issued an ad 
hoc report on the micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises finance gap, covering 128 countries 
including 29 ADB DMCs. However, the data for calculating financing gaps are based on survey 
findings, and available data items are limited. The Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and 
East Asia has issued the ASEAN SME Policy Index in collaboration with the Organisation for 
Economic Co-operation and Development, providing six scale ratings to eight policy dimensions 
based on descriptive analysis. This report, however, does not deliver country SME data. The DMC 
governments often utilize the World Bank Doing Business Report to measure the effectiveness of 
the  enabling  business  environment  for  SMEs  in  developing  Asia,  but  the  report  uses  a 
standardized SME definition not linked to country definitions. This suggests that it may not always 
reflect the actual condition of SMEs in the countries. The Asia SME Monitor will avoid duplication 
with existing SME data initiatives but add value to such initiatives through close collaboration and 
partnerships with DMCs.  
 
11.  Through the TA, the TA team will upgrade the Asia SME Monitor by strengthening its 
global reach and comparability to make it a benchmark on SME policy discussions in Asia and 
the Pacific. Following the direction of Strategy 2030, the TA team will focus on producing 
operationally relevant knowledge products, including pilot project proposals and a comparative 
index on SME development. The TA team will also develop knowledge cooperation with centers 
of excellence such as the Asian Development Bank Institute (ADBI) and the United Nations 
Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (ESCAP) to strengthen the quality of 
analysis. The long interval since the last Asia SME Monitor was launched in 2015 will not

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
12.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: private-sector-led economic growth promoted 
through the expansion of viable SME bases in DMCs. The TA will have the following outcome: 
SME business environment improved through enhanced evidence-based policy making on SME 
development in DMCs. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
13.  The proposed TA has three outputs: (i) SME-DI designed, (ii) pilot projects supporting 
SME development operations identified, and (iii) upgraded edition of Asia SME Monitor delivered. 
The TA will contribute to strengthening the connection among knowledge, finance, and technology 
in close collaboration with DMC governments, ADB operations departments, and knowledge 
partners. 
 
14.  Output 1: Small and Medium-Sized Enterprise Development Index designed. The TA 
team will design and test the SME-DI to measure two dimensions affecting SME development in 
the DMCs: (i) finance areas including banking, nonbank sectors, capital markets, public financing, 
financial infrastructure, technology adoption (financial technology or digital financial services 
solutions), and finance policies and regulations; and (ii) nonfinance areas including firm size, 
employment (skilled labor and gender), business productivity, market access, technology (e-
commerce and innovation), management and capacity of SMEs, external support (incubators and 
business development services), networking, and SME development policies and regulations. 
The SME-DI will introduce a multivariate analytical approach based on available country data, 
supplementary surveys, and social and academic databases to comprehensively measure the 
level of SME development in participating DMCs and the five ADB regions. The TA strategically 
targets countries from ASEAN for the Asia SME Monitor to be launched in 2020 and will expand 
the country coverage in 2021 and after.12 The TA team will decide the selection of countries 
through close consultation with ADB operations departments and DMCs, and demonstrate the 
pilot SME-DI in the planned Asia SME Monitor in 2020, which ADB will develop in partnership 
with ADBI and ESCAP. 
 
15.  Output  2:  Pilot  projects  supporting  small  and  medium-sized  enterprise 
development operations identified. The TA team will identify at least two innovative knowledge 
solutions supporting SME development, in close consultation with ADB operations departments 
and DMCs. ADBI and ESCAP, as knowledge partners, will also contribute to identifying such 
solutions. The Asia SME Monitor will demonstrate these solutions in its thematic chapter. ADB 
operations departments will accept at least two pilot projects using identified knowledge solutions 
for future work plans and project proposal discussions under various ADB country partnership

strategies. The TA team will establish a consultative group on the Asia SME Monitor to discuss 
themes for pilot project case studies, select candidate DMCs, and evaluate the findings from the 
Asia SME Monitor on a regular basis. The ERCD–Financial Cooperation and Integration team 
and the Regional Cooperation and Integration Thematic Group of the Sustainable Development 
and Climate Change Department will organize the consultative group, members of which will be 
widely sought from ADB operations departments and sector and/or thematic groups.     
 
16.  Output 3: Upgraded edition of Asia Small and Medium-Sized Enterprise Monitor 
delivered. The TA team will publish three volumes of the Asia SME Monitor as an annual 
periodical. The upgraded Asia SME Monitor has three components: (i) a regional review chapter 
demonstrating the result of the SME-DI, (ii) a thematic case discussion chapter addressing 
innovative knowledge solutions on SME development useful for ADB operations, and (iii) a 
country review chapter analyzing financial and nonfinancial issues in SME development in 
participating DMCs. To collect reliable and accurate data with periodic updates, the TA will build 
strategic partnerships on data sharing with key DMC institutions that hold SME data such as SME 
agencies, relevant line ministries, statistics offices, central banks, financial authorities, and SME 
banks. The TA team will organize at least three dissemination seminars (Asia SME Monitor book 
launch) in selected DMCs and/or ADB headquarters. The TA team will also conduct at least six 
training programs on SME development and access to finance for DMC governments and relevant 
stakeholders, based on the findings from the Asia SME Monitor and pilot project case studies. 
The TA team will share internally and disclose to the public collected data and analyses authorized 
by partner DMC institutions through the Asia SME Monitor Online, an open data portal. The Asia 
SME Monitor in 2020 will initially target ASEAN countries and will be expanded in 2021 and after, 
with  consideration  for  the  demand  from  DMCs  and  after  consulting  with  ADB  operations 
departments. The Asia SME Monitor defines SMEs according to the national classification by law 
or by policy guidelines adopted in participating DMCs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,600,000, of which (i) $600,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6), and (ii) $1,000,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction. The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 2.

Chief Economist and Director General of ERCD will play leading roles in the Asia SME Monitor. 
They will also serve as resource persons in field discussions with DMCs whose mission costs will

19.  Consulting  services.  The  TA  will  require  15  person-months  of  services  from  an 
international consulting firm, and 31 person-months of international and 62 person-months of 
national  individual  consultancy  services  comprising  (i)  18  person-months  for  a  lead  SME 
development international specialist, (ii) 7 person-months for an SME development training 
international expert, (iii) 6 person-months for an international editor of the Asia SME Monitor, (iv) 
56 person-months for two national SME data analysts (ADB headquarters), and (v) 6 person-
months for a data portal national expert. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB 
Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  its  associated  project 
administration instructions and/or staff instructions.13  
 
20.  Knowledge cooperation. The deliverables from knowledge partners, i.e., ADBI and 
ESCAP, will focus on the methodological development and implementation of the planned SME-
DI (output 1) and application of identified knowledge solutions for operations (output 2). ADBI’s 
activities are aligned with ADB’s strategic focus, which includes poverty reduction and inclusive 
economic growth, regional cooperation and integration, and private sector development and 
operations. ESCAP is the regional development arm of the United Nations for the Asia–Pacific 
region, whose support focuses on areas including macroeconomic policy, poverty reduction, and 
financing for development. The knowledge cooperation with partner institutions does not include 
the transfer of funds for full ADB administration.  
 
21.  Pilot testing of project approach. The scope of pilot testing covers challenges and 
opportunities affecting SME development and access to finance in DMCs, and helping ADB 
operations formulate new ideas for SME projects. ADB as the executing agency will coordinate 
the selection of the pilot project case studies and the participating DMCs in consultation with ADB 
operations departments. The activities will not result in any potential adverse environmental 
and/or social impacts. The TA team will prepare the details of the pilot project during TA 
implementation. 
 
22.  ADB’s procurement. ADB will subscribe to databases and purchase software necessary 
to implement the SME-DI, field surveys, and the pilot project case studies. The procurement 
method will be shopping, with three contracts. Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers 
(2017, as amended from time to time). 
 
23.  Social media and websites. Timely updates of the Asia SME Monitor Online are an 
integral part of its function. The TA team will explore arrangements for website maintenance 
before the closing of the project, if the demand on such open data portals persists.

E.  Governance 
 
24.  An ADB staff team from the ERCD will monitor and administer individual contracts and 
manage outputs to achieve TA objectives. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $1,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction, and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a 
grant basis for Upgrading the Asia Small and Medium-Sized Enterprise Monitor, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.
